Erowid name: zopiclone
Category: PHARMS
Field: MainPage

                    Text: 
                    Zopiclone / Eszopiclone



COMMON & BRAND NAMES

Imovane; Lunesta; Zimovane; [...]

EFFECTS CLASSIFICATION

Hypnotic; Sleep-aid

CHEMICAL NAME

4-methyl-1-piperazinecarboxylic acid 6-(5-chloro- 2-pyridinyl)-6,7-dihydro-7-oxo-5H-pyrrolo[3,4-b] pyrazin-5-yl ester

DESCRIPTION

Zopiclone is a short-acting sedative-hypnotic used in the short-term treatment of insomnia. It is in a novel class of CNS depressants called cyclopyrrolones, which act on the same receptor sites as benzodiazapines. Zopiclone became commercially available in Europe in 1989 and in the U.S. -- as eszopiclone, its active (S) stereoisomer -- in 2005. It is known for causing a metallic taste in the mouth, which the others in its class (zolpidem, zaleplon) do not.

BASICS

EFFECTS

IMAGES

HEALTH

LAW

DOSE

CHEMISTRY

LAW #

DEA Proposes Moving Zopliclone to Schedule IV, Feb 14, 2005

RELATED VAULTS #

ADDICTION & TREATMENT #

                    Context: 
                    This chunk provides an overview of Zopiclone/Eszopiclone within Erowid's Pharmaceuticals Vault, detailing its common and brand names, effects classification as a hypnotic sleep-aid, chemical name, description, and history of medical use. It links to sections on basics, effects, health, law, dose, chemistry, related substances (such as zolpidem and benzodiazepines), addiction and withdrawal notes, and references a law proposal and external resources. It is part of a comprehensive index covering psychoactive substances, their uses, effects, legal status, and user experiences.
